title: Humboldt Broncos crash survivor scores Adidas ad
text:
Sledge hockey player also nominated for Canada’s Sports Hall of Fame award

When Ryan Straschnitzki was paralyzed from the chest down in an April 2018 bus crash that killed 16 of his hockey team's players and staff, he wasn’t sure he’d ever get to play the game again.

Now, with the release of a 60-second Adidas ad, the 20-year-old from Airdrie, Alta., has proven that he’s still in the game.

The short video is the first ad to feature Straschnitzki after the player signed a three-year contract with the major sportswear company in June.

Straschnitzki got on the company’s radar after he started playing sledge hockey — an Olympic sport where players with physical disabilities use sledges instead of skates and two short hockey sticks to move on the ice and manoeuvre the puck.

He turned to sledge hockey after he was injured when a semi truck ran a stop sign and crashed into a bus carrying his junior hockey team — the Humboldt Broncos.

“When one door closes, another one opens,” Straschnitzki says in the new ad.

After the crash, Straschnitzki made it his goal to join Canada’s sledge hockey team and win a gold medal at the Paralympic Games.

“As a kid, I dreamed of playing for Team Canada,” he says in the commercial. “I still do.”

When he first signed the deal with Adidas, Straschnitzki said it was an “awesome feeling.”

He said he’s happy with the way the first ad worked out even though, he joked, he doesn’t have the looks of a typical TV star.

Adidas “made me look good,” he said, “so I can’t complain.”

Canada’s Sports Hall of Fame honoured Straschnitzki this month by nominating him and 15 other athletes for its first People’s Choice Award.

Cheryl Bernard, the Hall of Fame’s president, called him a role model.

“I look at what he’s done, and I don’t think I would have it in me,” she said. “I think that message is what the public needs to see.”

Straschnitzki returned to Humboldt, Sask., for the first time since the crash a couple of weeks ago for the Broncos’ season opener.

He said he was relieved to see that the atmosphere in the arena hadn’t changed.

“The town loves to go to the games.”

With files from Bill Graveland/CBC News, The Canadian Press
description: Adidas releases an ad featuring former Humboldt Bronco Ryan Straschnitzki, who now plays sledge hockey and dreams of playing for Canada.
